item.title: Bootstrap 5
item.description: Bootstrap 5 has officially landed! After three alphas, three betas, and several months of hard work, we’re shipping the first stable release of our new major version. It’s been a wild ride made possible by our maintainers and the amazing community that uses and contributes to Bootstrap. Thanks to all who have helped us get here!

item.title: How I Hacked Google App Engine: Anatomy of a Java Bytecode Exploit
item.description: Back in college, I was very interested in Java bytecode. When I got an internship at Google in 2013, I was skeptical of the security of the Java version of Google App Engine and got permission to spend the last week of my internship doing a mini red team exercise, trying to break into App Engine. This is the story of how I found a vulnerability and developed an exploit to break out of the App Engine sandbox and get arbitrary code execution on a Google server.

item.title: Lessons from Yahoo - Rui Zhi Dong
item.description: Verizon has announced that it sold off Yahoo and AOL to Apollo for about $5 billion. As I consider Yahoo’s history, I think about lessons that we can learn from their fall from grace. As Charlie Munger once said, “All I Want To Know Is Where I’m Going To Die So I’ll Never Go There.” <a href="https://ruizhidong.com/lessons-from-yahoo/" class="read-more">Continue Reading</a>

item.title: Preserving the Web
item.description: As Sarah and I were in the middle of moving, packing our lives into cardboard boxes, we unearthed a bunch of old laptops. Before donating them, I cracked them open to back everything up — and found a ton of old websites I’d worked on over the years. Rather than just shuffle the files endlessly between hard drives, I resolved to get them all online. Enter jake.museum: an online collection of my web design and development work, from 2007 to the present day.

item.title: Why is coroutine_handle::resume() potentially-throwing? | The Old New Thing
item.description: In our explorations of making co_awaitable objects, we had largely been ignoring the possibility of the coroutine handle throwing an exception upon resume. But according to the language specification, the resume method (and its equivalent, the operator() overloaded function call operator) is potentially-throwing.
